awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Lowering Wind Power Costs Through Robust Vertical-Axis Turbines
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is a reduction in consumer electricity costs, reduced stress on the electricity grid, and increased energy security. Technological advances in large wind turbines will enable power generation for communities and businesses at less than the average cost of utility generation and roof-top solar, and half the average cost of competing small wind turbines. This process would not fluctuate in time as much as solar installations, decreasing stress on grid infrastructure. Locally-owned generation will alleviate fluctuating energy prices and protect against grid failure. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project proposes to reduce the cost of wind energy from small wind turbines by at least 60%, making low-cost distributed renewable energy an affordable reality for communities and businesses. Vertical-axis wind turbines (VAWTs) have the potential for lower capital and maintenance costs than traditional horizontal-axis machines due to their mechanical simplicity. However, low efficiency and structural failure have plagued previous VAWT commercialization efforts. This SBIR Phase II project will optimize several subsystems and components of the drivetrain and rotor for efficiency, cost, and robustness in extreme environmental conditions through analysis, bench-top testing, and field experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
XFlow Energy is developing vertical-axis wind turbines (VAWTs) that reduce the cost of wind energy compared to state-of-the-art turbines of similar power output. Through NSF-supported research, this project focused on developing the technologies needed for a full-scale demonstration, proving XFlow's value propositions of lower lifetime costs and high efficiency. This included a) designing a low cost and efficient rotor capable of withstanding the harsh fatigue loading which has limited the success of VAWTs in the past, b) developing and rigorously testing a long life and low cost powertrain system, c) developing advanced wind turbine control algorithms to maximize energy capture, and d) fabrication and testing of a 25 kW prototype. Leveraging the data collected and lessons learned during this NSF award, XFlow is performing a final redesign prior to commercialization. 

XFlow's technology will reduce the cost of electricity for customers. This turbine will provide communities and businesses with a levelized cost of energy of less than $0.10/kWh at sites with an average wind of 6 m/s. Costs will be further reduced as XFlow's technology matures and product offerings include larger and larger turbines. Widespread adoption of XFlow's turbines will provide generation spread evenly across time and space when compared to roof-top solar, which has increased stress on grid distribution and peak demand requirements. Evening out renewable energy generation will decrease the required base load generation from fossil fuels. Energy security will also be increased by providing a locally owned and operated energy source to customers. Turbine installations will be especially impactful in regions affected by fluctuating energy prices or utility grid failure due to manmade or natural disasters. Together, these benefits will lead to energy savings for consumers, expand the use of wind power production, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.


 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Benjamin Strom
